question: Q9: The Aloha and S-Aloha protocols
options: To avoid interference between broadcasts of users sharing a broadcast channel assign to each user a predetermined time interval in which to transmit

They do not implement any prior checking to avoid interference between user transmissions who share a broadcast channel; only in the case of interference (collision) is action taken by repeating the transmission after a fixed delay

They do not implement any prior checking to avoid interference between user transmissions who share a broadcast channel; only in the case of interference (collision) is it intervened, repeating the transmission after a random delay
answer: Explanation: Aloha has low efficiency because the nodes transmit without coordinating with each other, only in the In the event of a collision, a backoff is performed: the two (or more) stations that have collided wait for a time random before retransmitting the PDU. The random time serves to break the determinism and if in the case the two (or more) stations waited for the same time, a collision with probability 1 would again occur. In this case doubles the maximum random waiting time.

Only on the host (host_id) part of the recipient's IP address

question: Q72: The DNS (Domain Name Service):
options: To increase the reliability and responsiveness of the system uses a set of caches, but each resolution must however always reach the authoritative server for the domain to which the first name

It is based on a system of hierarchical servers, each responsible for naming a particular zone
Represents a product to distribute the load on multiple routers within the local network
answer: Explanation: The DNS (Domain Name Service) is a system used for resolving the names of the nodes of the network (host) in IP addresses. The service is implemented through a distributed database, consisting of DNS servers.

question: Q73: Which of the following statements in the comparison between the Aloha and Slotted-Aloha protocols is false?
options: Slotted-Aloha allows a better exploitation of the capacity of the transmission medium
The performance of Aloha is less dependent than Slotted-Aloha on propagation delays
Aloha is simpler to implement by not requiring slot synchronization
answer: Explanation: The Slotted Aloha protocol adds another one to the Aloha protocol characteristic, that is, that time is divided into discrete intervals called slots. The consequence of this characteristic is that two transmissions either completely collide within the same slot or they do not collide at all; the problem of partial collisions present in Aloha is eliminated. (Source Wikipedia)

question: Q74: In the case of packet switching

question: Q76: Internet routing tables

question: Q77: Data transfer between two application processes in the OSI model occurs by involving

An entity in each system, independent of the level to which they belong

question: Q78: Consider two LANs Ethernet A and B, connected by a switch B1 and a router R1 (B1 and R1 are in parallel between the two LANs). options: The packet is forwarded on LAN B only by router R1

The packet is forwarded on LAN B by both router R1 and switch B1
answer: Explanation: The router receives the ARP and recognizes that it is intended for it via the payload. So don't forward it but it replies to the host that requested the MAC. The switch, being the ARP packet sent in broadcast, is forwards to all its gates except the one from which it received it. Page 19

question: Q79: The SMTP protocol

question: Q83: The CSMA and CSMA-CD protocols

question: Q86: Statistical multiplexing means

question: Q88: If a router receives a correct TCP packet, encapsulated in an IP packet with header destined for a non-existent TCP port (for which there is no application process in wait)

Ignore the TCP port value and send the packet
Discard it and send an ICMP packet to the source

question: Q89: The increment of the current window of the TCP transmitter

question: Q90: The CSMA and CSMA-CD protocols admit 1-persistent and non-persistent versions

In the case of the non-persistent version, if listening to the channel indicates that it is busy, the attempt is proposed for a random delay; in the case of 1-persistent versions, if listening to the channelindicates that it is busy, the transmission begins as soon as the current transmission ends
In both cases, if listening to the channel indicates that it is busy, the transmission attempt it is postponed with a random delay

question: Q91: Suppose that between a transmitter and a receiver they implement an ARQ scheme (Automatic repeat request) of the Go-Back-N type the time that elapses between the start of the transmission of a data unit and the end of receipt of the corresponding acknowledgment is constant and greater than the time necessary to transmit the information that can be stored in the transmission window. Increases the amount of information transferred on average in the unit of time between the transmitter and the receiver

question: Q93: In the event of a loss of segments identified by receiving three hits, the current window size of the reno TCP transmitter

question: Q99: Statistical multiplexing

question: Q100: In a packet-switched network operating in store-and-forward mode, a larger data unit size

question: Q107: If a router detects an incorrect checksum on an IP packet, and therefore a potential erroron the IP addresses contained in the packet, during the routing phase

question: Q112: In the IP header, or in the PCI of the IP protocol, they are contained

question: Q115: The DHCP protocol provides that

question: Q124: To avoid blocking or loss of data units in a windowed protocol due to channels non-sequential, it is useful

Number the PDUs on a number of bits greater than 1 and limit the life time of the PDUs in the network
Number the PDUs on a single bit and limit the life time of the PDUs in the network

question: Q125: The constraints on the maximum extension of an IEEE 802.3 local network (CSMA / CD) arise
options: Both from the propagation delay of the signals from one end of the network to the other, and from the attenuation of the signals on the transmission media. Page 30
Both from the attenuation of the signals on the transmission media and from the maximum delays tolerated by the users MAC service
By the number of bits that would be needed to increase the data units in the case of large delays propagation

question: Q126: In the case in which a window protocol is used on a channel that does not allow inversions in the sequence order of the data units transmitted (ie on a sequential channel), assuming use a non-cyclic progressive numbering, the transmission and reception windows cannot never find yourself in the following situation:
options: No sequence number included in the receive window is also included in the window transmission
The smallest sequence number in the transmission window is smaller than the smallest sequence number in the receiving window
The smallest sequence number in the receive window is smaller than the smallest number of sequence in the transmission window.
The largest sequence number in the receive window is larger than the largest number of sequence in the transmission window
answer: Explanation: A is possible in case all packets have been received but still no ACK is arrived at the transmitter. B and D are both the case where the receiver window is advanced but the transmitter has not yet received ACK. C cannot occur because the send window can advance only after receiving ACKs which must be sent by the receiver after the receiving a packet, but receiving it would necessarily involve a slide forward of the receiver, therefore the receiver never falls behind the transmitter.

question: Q127: Medium Access Control (MAC) sublevel protocols serve purpose

question: Q128: Which of the following statements is true?A) In the commercial standard Ethernet (CSMA / CD access protocols), one is defined minimum packet size to ensure correct collision identification

question: Q137: Which of the following statements is true?
options: A T1 topology, with N nodes, C channels and M1 average distance, always allows one to be disposed of lower amount of traffic of a T2 topology, with N nodes, C channels and average distance M2> M1, only with traffic evenly distributed between nodes.

A T1 topology, with N nodes, C channels and M1 average distance, always allows one to be disposed of traffic quantity lower than a T2 topology, with N nodes, C channels and average distance M2> M1, regardless of the traffic distribution.

The amount of traffic disposed of in a T1 topology, with N nodes, C channels and average distance M1, with respect to to that disposed of in a T2 topology, with N nodes, C channels and average distance M2> M1, depends on the traffic distribution between nodes
answer: Explanation: With the same capacity available on the channels, the amount of traffic that can be disposed of by a network depends on the average of the distances between each pair of nodes on the network (slide: Topologies and performance).

question: Q138: The main differences between a Frame Relay network and an Internet IP network are possible include:

The transfer of information in connection-oriented rather than non-connection-oriented mode connection
Transfer of data units of variable size instead of fixed size
answer: Explanation: Frame relay uses virtual circuit and not datagram (as IP does). They both use packages of variable size.

question: Q141: The size of the current TCP transmitter window during a connection

answer: Explanation: the level of congestion determines the cwnd and therefore the twnd

question: Q142: In the event of a segment loss identified by receiving three hits, the size of the current TCP transmitter window
options: It is brought to a value equal to half of the threshold
It is brought to a value equal to the threshold value
It is returned to the initial value, equal to one segment
answer: Explanation: The 3 hits correspond to the reception of 3 duplicate ACKs, the rest in the congestion phase avoidance with halving the cwnd, so A is the right answer (TCP reno).

question: Q145: Common channel signaling
options: It requires the use of signaling messages that contain the identifier of the connection to which they refer to Page 35
It is only used in packet-switched networks, because in circuit, the associated channel signaling technique is used
It cannot be used in cell or packet switched networks because it is too difficult identify connections in these networks without associating them with a signaling channel
It makes use of common transmission channels that are associated with each connection being made opening the connection itself
answer: Explanation: A is the definition of common channel signaling: a separate managed channel a packet switching, where each packet contains the signaling information that it concerns a specific controlled channel and the identification of the connection. B: channel signalingcommon is typically used in telephone networks (circuit switching). C: without meaning. D: associated channel definition. Source: videolessons.

question: Q146: Code division multiplexing

it is a special case of frequency division only

it does not necessarily need to be coupled to time or frequency multiplexing
answer: Explanation: A and B are false, C is incorrect because the toggle is node sharing, not del physical medium, while multiplexing is the way in which the physical medium is divided. Source: videolessons.

question: Q148: A Go-Back-N window protocol provides that:
options: when a packet is received with an error, the last N data units are retransmitted
the transmitter receives feedback for the last N data units transmitted before it can start transmission of other data units
the transmitter cannot send more than N data units before having received one or more acknowledgments
every time a time-out expires, the data unit whose sequence order is equal to is retransmitted sequence number of the last transmitted data unit decreased by N
answer: Explanation: A: retransmission occurs with timeout and not with packets received with errors. B: enough receive an ACK to advance the window. D: The timeout may expire while the window and the rule is not to retransmit going backwards, but to retransmit the contents of the window. Source: videolessons.

question: Q153: Which of these statements about TCP's retransmission mechanism is false?
